title: Imaging and Analysis of Quantum Materials, Developments in Workflow and Infrastructure
content: New Topological Insulators (TI) quantum materials with fascinating properties has caused great excitement and promises to transform device design and computation. Remarkably, some of the quantum phenomena displayed by these materials now persists at room temperature, opening the way for usable devices. We have done studies for example of TI's such as Ba6Nb11S28 [1]. This material naturally realizes vdW coupled heterointerfaces between transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) monolayers (hexagonal NbS2, H-NbS2) and insulating spacers Ba3NbS5. Low Energy Electron Diffraction (LEED) taken along the c-axis shows that the hexagonal spacer and TMD layers, are commensurate. The electronic band structure can be understood as that resulting from superimposing a periodic potential defined by Ba3NbS5 onto monolayer H-NbS2. This is the mechanism which yields flat energy bands and correlated physics in twisted-bilayer graphene and TMD heterostructures and is one of the key advances in the prediction of band structure and properties.
